qa_list.question: What is the maximum number of units a student in the MIIS program can take per semester without permission from the program director?
qa_list.answer: A student in the program may not take more than sixty (60) units per semester without permission from the program director.

qa_list.question: What is the minimum number of units a student in the MIIS program must be registered for to be considered a full-time student?
qa_list.answer: A student in the program must be registered for a minimum thirty-six (36) units per semester to be considered a full-time student.

qa_list.question: Are international students required by US Federal law to maintain full-time status?
qa_list.answer: Yes, all international students are required by US Federal law to maintain full-time status.

qa_list.question: Is it permitted for MIIS students to have a Reduced Course Load?
qa_list.answer: No, reduced course load is not permitted for MIIS students.

qa_list.question: What happens if an MIIS student fails to maintain full-time status?
qa_list.answer: Failure to maintain full-time status will result in loss of a student visa (and, therefore, “permit of stay”).

qa_list.question: Are pass/fail grades permitted for courses used to satisfy a degree requirement in MIIS?
qa_list.answer: No, pass/fail grades are not permitted for courses used to satisfy a degree requirement except for the 11-696 (A) Capstone Planning Seminar and 11-935 (R) LTI Practicum.

qa_list.question: Can graduate students who need additional undergraduate courses to build up their core foundations of computer science elect the pass/fail option for these courses?
qa_list.answer: No, graduate students who are required to take additional undergraduate courses to build up the core foundations of computer science may not elect the pass/fail option for these courses.

qa_list.question: Can an equivalent graduate course previously completed at Carnegie Mellon or another institution be used to satisfy one of the MIIS breadth requirements?
qa_list.answer: Yes, an equivalent graduate course previously completed at Carnegie Mellon, or another institution may be permitted to satisfy one of the MIIS breadth requirements.

qa_list.question: Does satisfying a breadth requirement with a course from another institution reduce the number of CMU course units that must be taken to attain the MIIS degree?
qa_list.answer: No, satisfying a breadth requirement with a course from another institution does not reduce the number of CMU course units that must be taken to attain the MIIS degree.

qa_list.question: What are the application materials required for transfer into the MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: The application materials required for transfer into the MIIS program include an explanation of why a transfer is desired, a proposed plan of study, a proposed advisor, and CMU transcripts.

qa_list.question: Are students already enrolled in an LTI degree program required to retake GRE and TOEFL/IELTS/Duolingo exams or produce new transcripts for transfer into the MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: No, students that are already enrolled in an LTI degree program are not required to retake GRE and TOEFL/IELTS/Duolingo exams or produce new transcripts from other universities.

qa_list.question: What is the expedited admissions process for students requesting transfer into the MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: The MIIS program will conduct an expedited admissions process after receiving a student's request for transfer. The program will consider whether the coursework done prior to the transfer allows the student to be 'on schedule' by the end of the spring semester, so that they can participate in a capstone project with other MIIS students during the next fall semester.

qa_list.question: Are MIIS students allowed to switch tracks after beginning their first semester at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Yes, MIIS students are allowed to switch tracks (MIIS-16 to MIIS-21 and vice versa) after beginning their first semester at CMU. Ideally, all switch requests should be filed within the first semester of the program.

qa_list.question: What are the restrictions on switching tracks for U.S. citizens in the MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: U.S. citizens have no restrictions on how many times they can switch if it is done for a legitimate reason. To confirm the legitimacy of the reason to switch tracks, all students must seek their advisor's approval and the approval of the Director of the MIIS program.

qa_list.question: What happens when a student transfers out of the MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: When a student transfers out of the MIIS program, they will be subject to additional financial obligations. It is highly recommended not to switch tracks more than once as multiple track switching may negatively impact immigration records for international students.

qa_list.question: What should students do if they want to transfer out of the MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: Students who wish to transfer out of the MIIS program should follow the standard procedures for leaving CMU and their specific degree program.

qa_list.question: What is the policy on track switching in the MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: Students are allowed to switch tracks (MIIS-16 to MIIS-21 and vice versa) after beginning their first semester at CMU. Ideally, all switch requests should be filed within the first semester of the program.

qa_list.question: What are the consequences for switching tracks multiple times in the MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: Multiple track switching may negatively impact immigration records for international students. It is highly recommended not to switch tracks more than once.

qa_list.question: What are the restrictions on switching tracks in the MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: U.S. citizens have no restrictions on how many times they can switch if it is done for a legitimate reason.

qa_list.question: Who must approve a student's request to switch tracks in the MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: All students must seek their advisor's approval and the approval of the Director of the MIIS program.

qa_list.question: Can students transfer out of the MIIS degree program?
qa_list.answer: Yes, students can transfer to another degree program. Each degree program has its own rules about whether and when transfers into the program are permitted.

qa_list.question: What should a student do if they want to transfer out of the MIIS degree program?
qa_list.answer: The student should consult the handbook and Program Director of the desired degree program to learn whether transfers are permitted, and if so, how, and when to request such a transfer.

qa_list.question: What is the statute of limitations for recording units required for the master’s degree?
qa_list.answer: All units must be recorded on the transcript within seven years of the date on which the student enrolled in the program, or less if required by a more restrictive department, school, or college policy.

qa_list.question: Can the statute of limitations for recording units be extended?
qa_list.answer: Yes, it can be extended by the SCS Associate Dean for Graduate Education for special circumstances that do not make it possible for the student to complete the requirements within the statutory period.

qa_list.question: Who must approve a waiver of the statute of limitations for the MIIS degree?
qa_list.answer: The request must be approved by the Department Head and by the SCS Associate Dean for Graduate Education.

qa_list.question: What should be included in a waiver request for the statute of limitations for the MIIS degree?
qa_list.answer: The waiver request must explain the exceptional circumstances that warrant an extension.

qa_list.question: Where can students find more information about the master’s degree statute of limitations policy at CMU?
qa_list.answer: They can visit https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-students-statute-of-limitations.html

qa_list.question: What does the LTI do when a student has completed graduate courses at another institution?
qa_list.answer: The LTI grants transfer credit or issues an exemption for equivalent graduate courses previously completed at another institution.

qa_list.question: How can a student replace a required course if they are exempt from it due to prior courses or experience?
qa_list.answer: If a student is exempt from a required course, they can replace that course with an open elective. The student does not receive credit for the external course but can take any course that could normally count toward the degree in its place.

qa_list.question: What happens if a student receives credit for prior coursework completed at CMU or elsewhere?
qa_list.answer: If a student receives credit for prior coursework completed at CMU or elsewhere, they receive that many units of credit. The total amount of required coursework is reduced by that amount.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: The information about the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook can be found on page 24 of the handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the decision-making process for granting transfer credit or issuing an exemption?
qa_list.answer: The decision to grant transfer credit or issue an exemption rests with the director of the program.

qa_list.question: Can a student take any course that could normally count toward their degree if they are exempt from a required course?
qa_list.answer: Yes, if a student is exempt from a required course due to prior courses or experience, they can replace that course with an open elective and take any course that could normally count towards the degree in its place.

qa_list.question: What happens when a student completes graduate courses at another institution?
qa_list.answer: When a student completes graduate courses at another institution, they can receive transfer credit or an exemption for equivalent graduate courses previously completed at another institution.

qa_list.question: How many units of credit does a student receive if they are exempt from a required course?
qa_list.answer: If a student is exempt from a required course due to prior courses or experience, the student can replace that course with an open elective. They do not receive any additional credit for the external course.

qa_list.question: What does it mean when a student receives transfer credit?
qa_list.answer: When a student receives transfer credit, they have completed courses at another institution that can be counted towards their degree requirements at CMU or MIIS. The total amount of required coursework is reduced by the number of units received.

qa_list.question: What are the restrictions on external employment and consulting in MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: External employment and consulting are strongly discouraged. Exceptional students who wish to consult should discuss this with their Advisor.

qa_list.question: What is the policy on Leave of Absence in MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: A student in good standing may be granted a LOA of at most 1 year, upon written request to the Program Director and with consent of the student's advisor.

qa_list.question: What happens if a MIIS student does not make satisfactory progress each semester?
qa_list.answer: The LTI may remove the student from the program or strongly encourage the student to consider switching to the four-semester program (MIIS-21) to complete all the requirements.

qa_list.question: What is the policy on winter and summer breaks for MIIS students supported by research projects?
qa_list.answer: Students are expected to remain on campus working during breaks in classes. A two-week vacation is typically allowed in the summer.

qa_list.question: Where can students with disabilities get assistance at CMU?
qa_list.answer: They can seek help from http://www.cmu.edu/education-office/disability-resources/

qa_list.question: What are students supported by research projects expected to do during winter and summer breaks?
qa_list.answer: Students supported by research projects are expected to remain on campus working during classes. A two-week vacation is typically allowed in the summer.

qa_list.question: How many weeks of vacation does a student take during winter break?
qa_list.answer: The normal winter break policy is that the student works 40 hours per week for two weeks and takes vacation for the other two weeks.

qa_list.question: What office at Carnegie Mellon University provides accommodations for students with disabilities?
qa_list.answer: The Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University has a continued mission to provide physical, digital, and programmatic access to ensure that students with disabilities have equal access to their educational experience.

qa_list.question: How can students who need accommodations begin the process of receiving them?
qa_list.answer: Students who would like to receive accommodations can begin the process through Disability Resources' secure online portal (https://rainier.accessiblelearning.com/cmu/) or email access@andrew.cmu.edu to begin the interactive accommodation process.

qa_list.question: What is the name of the handbook where this information can be found?
qa_list.answer: MIIS Graduate Student Handbook

qa_list.question: On which page of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook can you find this information?
qa_list.answer: Page 25

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University according to their mission statement?
qa_list.answer: The Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University has a continued mission to provide physical, digital, and programmatic access to ensure that students with disabilities have equal access to their educational experience.

qa_list.question: What laws guarantee the right for qualified individuals to receive reasonable accommodations?
qa_list.answer: The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973

qa_list.question: What is the name of the secure online portal where students can begin the process of receiving accommodations?
qa_list.answer: https://rainier.accessiblelearning.com/cmu/

qa_list.question: What kind of discrimination is prohibited by the University?
qa_list.answer: The University prohibits sex-based discrimination, sexual harassment, sexual assault, dating/domestic violence, and stalking.

qa_list.question: Where can students find the Sexual Misconduct Policy of the University?
qa_list.answer: The Sexual Misconduct Policy is available at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/sexual-misconduct/index.html.

qa_list.question: What should students do if they have been impacted by any of the issues mentioned in the text?
qa_list.answer: Students who have been impacted by these issues are encouraged to make contact with the Office of Title IX Initiatives, University Police or other resources listed.

qa_list.question: What is the URL for the Policy Against Retaliation at the University?
qa_list.answer: The Policy Against Retaliation can be found at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/whistleblower.html.

qa_list.question: What is the contact information for the Office of Title IX Initiatives?
qa_list.answer: The contact information for the Office of Title IX Initiatives is https://www.cmu.edu/title-ix/, 412-268-7125, tix@cmu.edu.

qa_list.question: Where can students find additional resources and information about these issues?
qa_list.answer: Additional resources and information can be found at MIIS Graduate Student Handbook Page 26.

qa_list.question: What kind of retaliation is prohibited by the University?
qa_list.answer: The University prohibits retaliation against individuals who bring forward concerns or allegations in good faith.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about the University Police?
qa_list.answer: Information about the University Police is available at https://www.cmu.edu/police/, 412-268-2323.

qa_list.question: What should students do if they need help with any of these issues?
qa_list.answer: Students who need help can contact the Office of Title IX Initiatives, University Police or other resources listed in the text.

qa_list.question: What accommodations are available for students who anticipate giving birth during a semester?
qa_list.answer: Students whose anticipated delivery date is during the semester may consider taking time away from their coursework and/or research responsibilities. Any student who gives birth to a child while engaged in coursework or research is eligible to take either a short-term absence or formal leave of absence.

qa_list.question: Who should students consult with as they begin making plans regarding time away?
qa_list.answer: Students are encouraged to consult with relevant university faculty and staff as soon as possible as they begin making plans regarding time away.

qa_list.question: What is the process for registering for Maternity Accommodations at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Students must contact the Office of the Dean of Student Affairs to register for Maternity Accommodations. Students will complete an information form and meet with a member of the Dean’s Office staff to determine resources and procedures appropriate for the individual student.

qa_list.question: What are some options available for students in course work during the semester of their anticipated birth?
qa_list.answer: Students in course work should consider options such as working with their course instructors to receive incomplete grades, electing to drop to part-time status or taking a full semester leave of absence.

qa_list.question: What are the accommodations available for students engaged in research during their anticipated birth?
qa_list.answer: Students engaged in research must work with their faculty to develop plans for the research for the time they are away and for resuming upon return.

qa_list.question: What is the policy regarding academic stipend funding during a Short-Term Maternity Accommodation or Formal Leave of Absence?
qa_list.answer: Master's students who receive an academic stipend funded by Carnegie Mellon are eligible to continue to receive stipend funding for up to six (6) weeks during a Short- Term Maternity Accommodation or a Formal Leave of Absence. Continued academic stipend funding may be extended by two (2) weeks, for a total of eight (8) weeks if an absence longer than six weeks is medically necessary.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements to receive continued academic stipend funding during a Short-Term Maternity Accommodation or Formal Leave of Absence?
qa_list.answer: To receive this support, students must be registered with the Office of the Dean of Students.

qa_list.question: What is the maximum duration for which academic stipend funding can be extended during a Short-Term Maternity Accommodation or Formal Leave of Absence?
qa_list.answer: Continued academic stipend funding may be extended by two (2) weeks, for a total of eight (8) weeks if an absence longer than six weeks is medically necessary.

qa_list.question: What should students consider when planning their return to course work or research after a Short-Term Maternity Accommodation or Formal Leave of Absence?
qa_list.answer: Students are encouraged to consult with relevant university faculty and staff as they begin making plans for returning to coursework or research.

qa_list.question: What is Employment Eligibility Verification?
qa_list.answer: Employment Eligibility Verification is a process that verifies whether an individual is legally authorized to work in the United States.

qa_list.question: Who needs to complete Form I-9 at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Anyone receiving a stipend from CMU or employed by CMU must complete Form I-9 within three business days following their first day of stipend start date/employment.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Employment Eligibility Verification Policy at CMU?
qa_list.answer: The policy aims to ensure compliance with federal law and maintains the university’s I-9 and E-Verify requirements.

qa_list.question: What happens if someone fails to complete Form I-9 within three business days at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Noncompliance may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment or stipend disbursement.

qa_list.question: What is the role of E-Verify in Employment Eligibility Verification at CMU?
qa_list.answer: E-Verify is a system used by CMU to verify the eligibility of employees to work in the United States.

qa_list.question: What happens if an individual's employment or stipend start date/employment does not align with their I-9 completion?
qa_list.answer: The individual must complete Form I-9 within three business days following their first day of stipend start date/employment.

qa_list.question: What is the Employment Eligibility Verification Policy at CMU?
qa_list.answer: It's a policy that outlines the university’s I-9 and E-Verify requirements, covering how to comply with federal law.

qa_list.question: What is Form I-9 used for in Employment Eligibility Verification at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Form I-9 is a document that verifies the identity and eligibility of an individual to work in the United States.

qa_list.question: What happens if someone has already completed Form I-9 but their employment or stipend start date/employment changes?
qa_list.answer: They must complete a new Form I-9 within three business days following their new first day of stipend start date/employment.

qa_list.question: What is the requirement for non-native English speakers in Pennsylvania?
qa_list.answer: According to state law, all students who are not native speakers of English must take and pass a proficiency test administered by the state.

qa_list.question: Where can students find support for teaching activities at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence, located in Warner Hall 425, provides support for teaching activities. Students who will be TAs are encouraged to visit the center and take advantage of its resources.

qa_list.question: Are students in professional master’s programs prohibited from seeking support as Teaching Assistants or Research Assistants?
qa_list.answer: No, they are not. However, full-time master's students usually do not have time for these activities.

qa_list.question: Can MIIS students apply for TA positions without the permission of the program director?
qa_list.answer: No, they cannot. Teaching Assistantships are discouraged for first-semester students.

qa_list.question: Where can graduate students find information about financial aid at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students should consult the Graduate Financial Aid Guide and other helpful links on The HUB website (http://www.cmu.edu/finaid/graduate/index.html).

qa_list.question: Is health insurance mandatory for full-time, degree-seeking students at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Yes, it is. Students must either purchase the plan offered by the university or apply for a waiver if they are covered under an employer or government-sponsored insurance plan.

qa_list.question: What happens if full-time, degree-seeking students do not have adequate medical insurance coverage?
qa_list.answer: They will be in violation of the university's policy and may face penalties or consequences.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about Carnegie Mellon University’s Student Health Insurance Policy?
qa_list.answer: The policy is available at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/student-health-insurance.html.

qa_list.question: What kind of insurance plan does the university offer for its students?
qa_list.answer: The specifics about the university's offered health insurance plan are not mentioned in this text, so it is unclear what type of plan they provide.

qa_list.question: What should students do regarding their insurance at the beginning of each semester?
qa_list.answer: Students are responsible for making arrangements with Student Health Services to either pay for their insurance upfront or elect a payment plan over the course of the academic year.

qa_list.question: Where can students find more information about student health services?
qa_list.answer: More information is available at the Student Health Services Web site www.studentaffairs.cmu.edu/HealthServices/insurance.

qa_list.question: Are all CMU students eligible for an emergency loan?
qa_list.answer: Yes, all students regardless of their program are eligible for the Emergency Student Loan.

qa_list.question: What is the repayment period for the Emergency Student Loan?
qa_list.answer: The Emergency Student Loan is an interest-free and emergency-based loan that must be repaid within 30 days.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: Information about the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook is available on Page 29 of the document.

qa_list.question: What should students do if they need an emergency loan?
qa_list.answer: Students can apply for the Emergency Student Loan, which is available through the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook on Page 29.

qa_list.question: Is there a specific program that students should check in their handbook to find information about emergency loans?
qa_list.answer: Yes, students can find information about emergency loans in the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook on Page 29.

qa_list.question: How long does it take for a student loan to be repaid?
qa_list.answer: The Emergency Student Loan must be repaid within 30 days of receiving the funds.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of an emergency loan?
qa_list.answer: An emergency loan is designed to provide students with immediate financial assistance in times of unexpected need or crisis.

qa_list.question: Where can students apply for the loan?
qa_list.answer: Students may apply for the loan by stopping into the Student Affairs Office, Warner Hall 301, or by calling (412) 268-2075 for an appointment.

qa_list.question: How can graduate students get emergency funding?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students who find themselves in need of immediate funds for emergency situations should contact the Office of the Dean of Students (see Appendix A), www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/index.html, to inquire about the types of emergency funding available to enrolled students.

qa_list.question: Where is The HUB Student Services Center located?
qa_list.answer: The HUB is located in Warner Hall, Lower Level.

qa_list.question: What does the Assistant Directors in The HUB do?
qa_list.answer: Assistant Directors in The HUB serve as contacts for specific colleges and assist enrolled students with key aspects of the enrollment process. Student can find their assigned HUB Assistant Director on their Student Information Online (SIO) Resource page.

qa_list.question: How can students get general information or ask questions to The HUB?
qa_list.answer: Students may email The HUB or call 412-268-8186 for general questions and information.

qa_list.question: What is the responsibility of MIIS students regarding address changes?
qa_list.answer: MIIS students are responsible for notifying the University of all address changes in a timely manner. Students will be held responsible for any failure to receive official college notices due to not having a correct address on file; F-1 students may jeopardize their status if address information is not kept current.

qa_list.question: How can MIIS students change their address?
qa_list.answer: Students can change their address using SIO, which is available via the HUB website (http://www.cmu.edu/hub/index.html).

qa_list.question: What are ID cards for graduate students?
qa_list.answer: ID cards identify their holders as members of the campus community. Student cards are deactivated upon the cardholder’s separation from the university.

qa_list.question: Who can obtain Affiliate ID Cards and how to get them?
qa_list.answer: Affiliate ID Cards are available for spouses and partners of graduate students that allow them to access Carnegie Mellon’s campus. These cards are available through The HUB to spouses and partners of graduate students who are enrolled for the current academic year in a full-time graduate degree program. The card is valid for one year.

qa_list.question: Where can I find more information about student and affiliate ID cards?
qa_list.answer: For more information about student and affiliate ID cards (spouse, domestic partners and dependent children), please visit: https://www.cmu.edu/idplus/idcards/index.html.

qa_list.question: Where can I find information about ordering transcripts?
qa_list.answer: Information about and instructions for ordering transcripts are available at: <https://www.cmu.edu/hub/registrar/student-records/transcripts/>. Transcript questions may be directed to uro-transcripts@andrew.cmu.edu.

qa_list.question: What is the Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) and what does it have to do with Cross-registration?
qa_list.answer: The Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) provides information about cross-registration, which allows students from participating institutions in the Pittsburgh area to take courses at other PCHE member schools. More information can be found at <https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-student-status.html>.

qa_list.question: What is the URL for ordering transcripts at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: https://www.cmu.edu/hub/registrar/student-records/transcripts/

qa_list.question: Where can students direct their questions about transcripts?
qa_list.answer: uro-transcripts@andrew.cmu.edu

qa_list.question: What is the name of the organization that offers cross-registration for Carnegie Mellon University students?
qa_list.answer: Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE)

qa_list.question: Does Carnegie Mellon University accept transfer credit from other accredited institutions? If so, how is this recorded on the transcript?
qa_list.answer: Yes, Carnegie Mellon University accepts transfer credit from other accredited institutions. This will be recorded on the transcript indicating where the course was taken.

qa_list.question: What does QPA stand for in relation to cross-registration courses at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: QPA stands for Quality Point Average, which is used to calculate a student's grade point average.

qa_list.question: According to the text, what will be recorded on a Carnegie Mellon transcript if a course was taken through cross-registration?
qa_list.answer: If a course is taken through cross-registration, it will have grades recorded on the transcript and be factored into the QPA.

qa_list.question: Where can students find more information about their student status at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Students can find more information about their student status at Carnegie Mellon University by visiting the following link: https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-student-status.html

qa_list.question: What is the name of the handbook that provides information for MIIS graduate students?
qa_list.answer: The MIIS Graduate Student Handbook

qa_list.question: What is the opportunity mentioned in this text?
qa_list.answer: The opportunity mentioned in this text is taking courses without grades.

qa_list.question: Why will such courses not be considered for academic actions, honors or QPA calculations?
qa_list.answer: Such courses will not be considered for academic actions, honors or QPA calculations because they are taken without grades.

qa_list.question: What should students do if they want to take advantage of this opportunity?
qa_list.answer: Students interested in taking advantage of this opportunity should be familiar with the Policy on Grades for Transfer Courses already outlined previously in this handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the university policy mentioned in this text?
qa_list.answer: The university policy notifies students of their rights under the federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA).

qa_list.question: According to FERPA, what are the student's rights?
qa_list.answer: According to FERPA, students have the right to inspect and review their education records; request an amendment to them.

qa_list.question: What is the federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA)?
qa_list.answer: The federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) is a law that protects student's privacy rights.

qa_list.question: What does FERPA allow students to do?
qa_list.answer: According to the text, FERPA allows students to inspect and review their education records; request an amendment to them.

qa_list.question: Why is it important for students to know about this university policy?
qa_list.answer: It's important for students to know about the university policy because it notifies them of their rights under FERPA, which protects student privacy rights.

qa_list.question: What is the Policy on Grades for Transfer Courses mentioned in this text?
qa_list.answer: The Policy on Grades for Transfer Courses is a previously outlined policy that students should be familiar with if they want to take advantage of the opportunity to take courses without grades.

doc_text:
it cannot be counted as a Qualifying course.
5.1.5 Maximum and Minimum Course Loads
A student in the program may not take more than sixty (60) units per semester without permission from the program director.
A student in the program must be registered for a minimum thirty-six (36) units per semester to be considered a full-time student or twelve (12) units per semester to be considered a part- time student. All international students are required by US Federal law to maintain full-time status. Reduced Course Load is not permitted for MIIS students. Failure to maintain full-time status will result in loss of a student visa (and, therefore, “permit of stay”). (MIIS policy)
5.1.6 Pass/Fail Grades
Pass/fail grades are not permitted for courses used to satisfy a degree requirement, except for the 11-696 (A) Capstone Planning Seminar and 11-935 (R) LTI Practicum that are a Pass/Fail. Graduate students who are required to take additional undergraduate courses to build up the core foundations of computer science may not elect the pass/fail option for these courses.
5.1.7 Transfer Credit
An equivalent graduate course previously completed at Carnegie Mellon, or another institution may be permitted to satisfy one of the MIIS breadth requirements. The decision on whether a course may be used to satisfy a breadth requirement is made by the MIIS Program Director. Typically, the student will provide the Program Director with the syllabus of the external course, and the Program Director will use that and the student’s transcript to make the decision.
Satisfying a breadth requirement with a course from another institution does not reduce the number of CMU course units that must be taken to attain the MIIS degree.
See the section on “Definition of transfer credit versus course exemption” on page 23.
5.1.8 Transferring Into the MIIS Program
Transfers into the MIIS program are not permitted during a student’s first semester at CMU. Students must begin their study at CMU in the program that admitted them.
Students may request to transfer into the MIIS program after completing their first semester and before the add/drop deadline of the spring semester. The student must make the request in writing (or email) to the MIIS Program Director. The MIIS Program Director will inform
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 22


the student about what application materials are required, for example, an explanation of why a transfer is desired, a proposed plan of study, a proposed advisor, and CMU transcripts. Students that are already enrolled in an LTI degree program are not required to retake GRE and TOEFL/IELTS/Duolingo exams or to produce new transcripts from other universities.
The MIIS program will conduct an expedited admissions process after receiving such a request. The program will explicitly consider whether the coursework done prior to the transfer will allow the student to be “on schedule” by the end of the spring semester, so that the student can participate in a capstone project with other MIIS students during the next fall semester.
MIIS students are allowed to switch tracks (MIIS-16 to MIIS-21 and vice versa) after beginning their first semester at CMU. Ideally, all switch requests must be filed within the first semester of the program. It is highly recommended to not switch tracks more than once! Though not forbidden, multiple track switching may negatively impact immigration records of international students. Students also must understand that extension of their stay in the program will lead to additional financial obligations.
U.S. citizens, virtually, have no restrictions on how many times they can switch if it is done for a legitimate reason. To confirm legitimacy of the reason to switch tracks ALL students must seek their advisor's approval and the approval of the Director of the MIIS program.
5.1.9 Transferring Out of the MIIS Program
The MIIS program does not prevent students from transferring to another degree program. Each degree program has its own rules about whether and when transfers into the program are permitted. A student that is interested in transferring out of the MIIS degree program should consult the handbook and Program Director of the desired degree program to learn whether transfers are permitted, and if so, how, and when to request such a transfer.
5.1.10 Statute of Limitations
All units required for the master’s degree, whether earned in residence or transferred from another institution, must be recorded on the transcript within seven years of the date on which the student enrolled in the program (CMU policy1), or less if required by a more restrictive department, school, or college policy. This statutory period can be extended by the SCS Associate Dean for Graduate Education for special circumstances that do not make it possible for the student to complete the requirements within the statutory period. Any request for a waiver of the statute of limitations for the MIIS degree must be approved by the Department Head and by the SCS Associate Dean for Graduate Education. The waiver request must explain the exceptional circumstances that warrant an extension. For cases in which a
1 https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-students-statute-of- limitations.html
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 23


waiver is granted, the waiver will cover specific courses and will specify a time period for completion of the program.
As outlined in the Master’s Students Statute of Limitations, https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-students-statute-of- limitations.html students will complete all requirements for the master’s degree within a maximum of seven years from original matriculation as a master’s student, or less if required by a more restrictive department, school or college policy. Once this time-to-degree limit has lapsed, the person may resume work towards a master’s degree only if newly admitted to a currently offered master’s degree program under criteria determined by that program.
Under extraordinary circumstances, such as leave of absence, military or public service, family or parental leave, or temporary disability, a school or college may, upon the relevant department's recommendation and with the written approval of the dean (or designate), defer the lapse for a period commensurate with the duration of that interruption. Students who are pursuing a master’s degree as part-time students for all semesters of their program, as approved by their program, may also appeal to their program or department for extension of the time to degree limit.
See also the ‘Duration of Study’ policy.
5.2 LTI Academic Policies
5.2.1 “Grandfather” policy
A student can graduate under the policies in effect at the time that the student entered the program; or, at the student's choice, the student can graduate under policies that are adopted after the student entered the program. If it is not realistic to follow a particular policy exactly, the department may approximate the policy as closely as possible; this situation is rare and typically arises only when a student is enrolled in the program for an extended period.
5.2.2 Definition of transfer credit versus course exemption
The LTI may grant transfer credit or issue an exemption for equivalent graduate courses previously completed at another institution. This decision rests with the director of the program. If a student is exempt from a required course due to prior courses or experience, the student can replace that course with an open elective. The student does not receive credit for the external course but can take any course that could normally count toward the degree in its place. If a student receives credit for prior coursework completed at CMU or elsewhere, the student receives that many units of credit, and the total amount of required coursework is reduced by that amount.
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 24


5.2.3 External Employment/Consulting
Since the MIIS program places heavy demands on student time, external employment and/or consulting are strongly discouraged. Exceptional students who wish to consult should discuss this with their Advisor. International students must also have approval in advance from the Office of International Education (OIE) for any outside employment.
5.2.4 Leave of Absence
The LTI discourages Leaves of Absence (LOA), since students usually do not return, despite good intentions. However, a student in good standing may be granted a LOA of at most 1 year, upon written request to the Program Director and with consent of the student's advisor. It is the responsibility of the student on LOA to contact the LTI to initiate a return to the program.
5.2.5 Satisfactory Progress
If a student does not make satisfactory progress each semester toward completing the degree, the LTI may remove the student from the program or strongly encourage the student to consider switching to the four-semester program (MIIS-21) to complete all the requirements. See section on “End of Semester Review” on page 17.
5.2.6 Winter and Summer Breaks
Students supported by research projects are expected to remain on campus working during breaks in classes. A two-week vacation is typically allowed in the summer. The normal winter break policy is that the student works 40 hours per week for two weeks and takes vacation for the other two weeks.
5.3 CMU Academic Policies
5.3.1 Assistance for Individuals with Disabilities
http://www.cmu.edu/education-office/disability-resources/
The Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University has a continued mission to provide physical, digital, and programmatic access to ensure that students with disabilities have equal access to their educational experience. We work to ensure that qualified individuals receive reasonable accommodations as guaranteed by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973. Students who would like to receive accommodations can begin the process through Disability Resources' secure online portal (https://rainier.accessiblelearning.com/cmu/) or email access@andrew.cmu.edu to begin the interactive accommodation process.
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 25


Students with physical, sensory, cognitive, or emotional disabilities are encouraged to self- identify with the Office of Disability Resources and request needed accommodations. Any questions about the process can be directed to access@andrew.cmu.edu, or call (412) 268- 6121.
5.3.2 Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures
Graduate students will find the Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures on the Graduate Education Resource webpage. This document summarizes processes available to graduate students who seek review of academic and non-academic issues. Generally, graduate students are expected to seek informal resolution of all concerns within the applicable department, unit, or program before invoking formal processes. When an informal resolution cannot be reached, however, a graduate student who seeks further review of the matter is to follow the formal procedures outlined here. These appeal and grievance procedures shall apply to students in all graduate programs of the University. Students should refer to the department specific information in this handbook for department and college information about the administration and academic policies of the program. Additionally, students may confer with the graduate student ombudsperson, Suzie Laurich- McIntyre, slaurichmcintyre@cmu.edu, on issues of process or other concerns as they navigate conflicts.
5.3.3 Policy Against Sexual Harassment and Sexual Assault
The University prohibits sex-based discrimination, sexual harassment, sexual assault, dating/ domestic violence, and stalking. The University also prohibits retaliation against individuals who bring forward such concerns or allegations in good faith.
The University’s Sexual Misconduct Policy is available at
https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/sexual-misconduct/index.html.
The University’s Policy Against Retaliation is available at
https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/whistleblower.html.
If you have been impacted by any of these issues, you are encouraged to make contact with any of the following resources:
 Office of Title IX Initiatives
https://www.cmu.edu/title-ix/, 412-268-7125, tix@cmu.edu
o
 University Police
o https://www.cmu.edu/police/, 412-268-2323
Additional resources and information can be found at:
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 26


https://www.cmu.edu/title-ix/resources-and-information/resources.html.
5.3.4 Childbirth/Maternity Accommodation Protocol
https://www.cmu.edu/graduate/programs-services/maternity-accommodation-protocol.html
Students whose anticipated delivery date is during the semester may consider taking time away from their coursework and/or research responsibilities. Any student who gives birth to a child while engaged in coursework or research is eligible to take either a short-term absence or formal leave of absence. Students are encouraged to consult with relevant university faculty and staff as soon as possible as they begin making plans regarding time away.
Students must contact the Office of the Dean of Student Affairs to register for Maternity Accommodations. Students will complete an information form and meet with a member of the Dean’s Office staff to determine resources and procedures appropriate for the individual student.
o Planning for the student’s discussion with appropriate academic contact(s)
(advisor, associate dean, etc.) may be reviewed during this meeting.
Students in course work should consider options for the semester of the anticipated birth such as working with their course instructors to receive incomplete grades, electing to drop to part-time status or taking a full semester leave of absence.
Students engaged in research must work with their faculty to develop plans for the research for the time they are away and for resuming upon return.
Master's students who receive an academic stipend funded by Carnegie Mellon are eligible to continue to receive stipend funding for up to six (6) weeks during a Short- Term Maternity Accommodation or a Formal Leave of Absence. Continued academic stipend funding may be extended by two (2) weeks, for a total of eight (8) weeks if an absence longer than six weeks is medically necessary. To receive this support students must be registered with the Office of the Dean of Students.
5.3.5 Consensual Intimate Relationship Policy Regarding Undergraduate
Students
https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/consensual-relationships.html
This policy addresses the circumstances in which romantic, sexual, or amorous relationships/interactions with undergraduate students, even if consensual, are inappropriate and prohibited. The purpose of this policy is to assure healthy professional relationships. This policy is not intended to discourage consensual intimate relationships unless there is a
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 27


conflicting professional relationship in which one party has authority over the other as in the policy.
5.3.6 Employment Eligibility Verification
If you are receiving a stipend, are a TA, or are planning to have a position with CMU then Employment Eligibility Verification is required. Form I-9 must be completed within 3 business days of beginning work for any type of compensation (stipend or employment). Additional details are highlighted below. To ensure compliance with federal law, Carnegie Mellon University maintains the Employment Eligibility Verification (I-9) Policy https://www.cmu.edu/hr/assets/hr/restrict/employment-eligibility-verification-policy.pdf covering the university’s I-9 and E-Verify requirements:
Every individual receiving a stipend from CMU or employed by CMU must comply with the I-9 Policy by completing the Form I-9 within three business days following the first day of stipend start date/employment.

Individuals who expect to work on a federally funded project are further responsible for submitting an E-Verify Processing Request Form to the Office of Human Resources if required.
For more information, please see CMU’s Guidance for Completing the Form I-9 and E-Verify Requirements at CMU https://www.cmu.edu/hr/assets/recruiting/restrict/i-9- guidance.pdf , or visit the Human Resources Service website to learn more about Form I-9 and E-Verify https://www.cmu.edu/hr/service-center/new-faculty-staff/i-9-e- verify/index.html and to schedule an appointment to complete the Form I-9 https://go.oncehub.com/I9Appointment.
6 Financial Issues
6.1 Graduate Student Funding
The LTI does not provide financial aid or support to students in the professional master’s programs. Students are encouraged to seek financial aid and support from other sources. The HUB website (https://www.cmu.edu/sfs/financial-aid/index.html) provides the Graduate Financial Aid Guide, information about funding options and how to apply for financial aid and other helpful links. Additional information on financial issues for graduate students can be found on the web at http://www.cmu.edu/hub/new-grad/.
Teaching assistantships are awarded to faculty members who then award these positions to selected students. Teaching assistant duties include, but are not limited to, holding office hours, conducting recitation classes, and grading. There are minimum English proficiency requirements that must be met for a student to accept a teaching assistantship. Pennsylvania
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 28


state law requires that all students who are not native speakers of English take and pass a state administered proficiency test. Support for teaching activities can be found through the Eberly Center for Teaching Excellence, located in Warner Hall 425. Students who will be T.A.s for the department are encouraged to visit the Teaching Center and to take advantage of the information and services located there.
Students in the professional master’s programs are not prohibited from seeking support as Teaching Assistants and Research Assistants. However, typically, fulltime master’s students do not have time for these activities. Research Assistantships are most likely to be awarded to students in CMU’s research-oriented degree programs.
MIIS students can apply for TA positions only with the permission of the program director. Teaching Assistantships are especially discouraged for first semester students.
6.2 University Financial Aid
Graduate students should consult the graduate student financial aid information found on The HUB website (http://www.cmu.edu/finaid/graduate/index.html.) Students will find the Graduate Financial Aid Guide, information about funding options and how to apply for financial aid and other helpful links.
6.3 Health Insurance
Carnegie Mellon has a Student Health Insurance policy requiring full-time, degree seeking students to carry adequate medical insurance. Students must either purchase the plan offered by the University or an application for a waiver can be made if the student is “enrolled as the dependent, partner/spouse or principal in an employer or government-sponsored insurance plan” (see the Carnegie Mellon University Student Health Insurance Policy at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/student-health-insurance.html.
It is the responsibility of each student to make arrangements with Student Health Services to either pay for their insurance at the beginning of the semester or elect a payment plan over the course of the academic year. More information is available at the Student Health Services Web site www.studentaffairs.cmu.edu/HealthServices/insurance.
6.4 Emergency Loans
https://www.cmu.edu/sfs/billing/emergency-loans.html
All students regardless of their program are eligible for the Emergency Student Loan, which is an interest-free and emergency-based loan repayable within 30 days. It is available through the
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 29


Office of the Dean of Student Affairs; students may apply for the loan by stopping into the Student Affairs Office, Warner Hall 301, or by calling (412) 268-2075 for an appointment.
6.5 Office of the Dean of Students Emergency Support Funding
Graduate students who find themselves in need of immediate funds for emergency situations should contact the Office of the Dean of Students (see Appendix A), www.cmu.edu/student- affairs/index.html, to inquire about the types of emergency funding available to enrolled students.
7 Additional University Resources
7.1 The HUB Student Services Center
thehub@andrew.cmu.edu and http://www.cmu.edu/hub/
The HUB is located in Warner Hall, Lower Level. The HUB staff delivers comprehensive service and counsel to students and families regarding financial aid, billing and payment, registration, and academic records. The Assistant Directors in The HUB serves as contacts for specific colleges and assist enrolled students with key aspects of the enrollment process. Student can find their assigned HUB Assistant Director on their Student Information Online (SIO) Resource page. Questions that need specialized, in-depth attention can be directed to the student's assigned Assistant Director. For general questions and information, students may email The HUB or call 412-268-8186.
7.2 Student Information Online (SIO)
Student Information Online (SIO) is a secure site where students can find important, personalized information, including E-Bills and student account information, financial aid status and eligibility, grades and QPA, and course schedules. Students can update their and their spouse's or domestic partner's contact information, sign up for E-Check & E-Refund, authorize their spouses, domestic partners or other individual to receive a copy of their E-Bill, request verifications, view their housing and meal plan assignments, and much more. Students can log on to SIO by going to www.cmu.edu/hub/sio and entering their Andrew User ID and password.
On SIO, students will designate an emergency contact address of a relative or family friend to be contacted in the case of an emergency. If students do not want their name and address published in the campus directory, they must notify the HUB in writing.
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 30


MIIS students are responsible for notifying the University of all address changes in a timely manner. Students will be held responsible for any failure to receive official college notices due to not having a correct address on file; F-1 students may jeopardize their status if address information is not kept current.
Students can change their address using SIO, which is available via the HUB website (http://www.cmu.edu/hub/index.html).
7.3 ID Cards
Graduate students can obtain their ID card from The HUB once they have been entered into SIO for the semester. These cards identify their holders as members of the campus community. Student cards are deactivated upon the cardholder’s separation from the university.
Affiliate ID Cards are available for spouses and partners of graduate students that allow them to access Carnegie Mellon’s campus. These cards are available through The HUB to spouses and partners of graduate students who are enrolled for the current academic year in a full-time graduate degree program. The card is valid for one year. For information about domestic partner registration, visit the Office of the Dean of Student Affairs webpage: https://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/dean/domestic-partner/index.html.
For more information about student and affiliate ID cards (spouse, domestic partners and dependent children), please visit: https://www.cmu.edu/idplus/idcards/index.html.
7.4 Transcripts
Information about and instructions for ordering transcripts are available at: https://www.cmu.edu/hub/registrar/student-records/transcripts/. Transcript questions may be directed to uro-transcripts@andrew.cmu.edu.
7.5 Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) and Cross-registration
https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-student- status.html
Carnegie Mellon University offers students the opportunity to take courses for credit through a cross-registration program (see Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) and Cross- registration below) and through the receipt of transfer credit from other accredited institutions. The Carnegie Mellon University transcript will include information on such courses as follows: Carnegie Mellon courses and courses taken through the university's cross- registration program will have grades recorded on the transcript and be factored into the QPA. All other courses will be recorded on this transcript indicating where the course was taken,
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 31


but without grades. Such courses will not be considered for academic actions, honors or QPA calculations.
Students interested in taking advantage of this opportunity should be familiar with the Policy on Grades for Transfer Courses already outlined previously in this handbook.
7.6 Student Privacy Rights and FERPA
https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/privacy-rights-students.html
This university policy notifies students of their rights under the federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). According to FERPA, students have the right to:
•
inspect and review their education records; request an amendment to
